intro: Mauria killipii, commonly known as the Hawaiian sea hibiscus, is a flowering plant native to the Hawaiian Islands. It belongs to the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its showy, five-petaled flowers that range in color from white to pink. The plant typically grows in coastal areas, thriving in sandy or rocky soils with ample sunlight. Its leaves are broad and lobed, often covered in fine hairs, and it produces capsule fruits that contain numerous seeds. Mauria killipii plays an important ecological role in its native habitat, supporting local pollinators and contributing to coastal vegetation.
